SP.P: And then, offring to kisse her hand, if she shall coyly recoyle, and signifie your repulse; you are to re-enforce your selfe with, More then most faire Lady; let not the Rigor of your iust disdaine thus coursly censure of your seruants zeale: and (with-all) protest her, To be the onely, and absolute vn-paraeleld Creature, you do adore, aud admire, and respect, and reuerence, in this Court, Corner of the world, or Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: This is hard by my faith: Ile begin it all againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Do so, and I will Act it for your Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Will you vouchsafe sir? All varietie of diuine pleasures, choise Sports, sweete Musique, rich Fare, brau Attire, soft Beds, and silken thoughts, attend this deare Beauty.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: So Sir, pray you a way.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: More then most faire Lady, let not the Rigor of your iust disdaine, thus coursly censure of your sruants zeale. I protest you are the only and absolute vn-aparailed—

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: Vn-paraleld.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Vn-paraleld Creature, I do adore, and admire, and respect, and reuerence, in this Court, Corner of the world, or kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P:
This is if shee abide you: But now; put case shee should be Passant when you enter, as thus: you are to frame your Gate ther'after, and call vpon her: Lady, Nimph,
Sweete Refuge, Starre of our Court: Then if shee be Guardant, here: you are to come on, and (aterally disposing your selfe,) sweare by her blushing and well coulored cheeke: the bright dye of her hayre, her Iuorie teeth, or some such white and Innocent oath, to induce you. If Reguardant; then, maintein your station, Briske, and Irpe, shew the supple motion of your plyant body: but (in chiefe) of your knee, and hand, which cannot but arride her proude Humor exceedingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: I conceiue you sir, I shall performe all these things in good time, I doubt not, they do so hit me.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: Well Sir, I am your Lady; make vse of any of these beginnings, or some other out of your owne inuention: and prooue how you can holde vp, and follow it. Say, Say.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Yes Sir: my deare Lindabrides.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: No, you affect that Lindabrides too much: And (let me tell you) it is not so Courtly. Your Pedant should prouide you some parcels of French, or some pretty Commodity of Ita∣lian to commence with, if you would be exotick, and exqui∣site.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Yes Sir, he was at my lodging t'other morning, I gau him a Doublet.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: Double your beneuolence, and giue him the Hose too; cloathe you his body, hee will helpe to apparaile your minde. But now, see what your proper Genius can performe alone, without adiection of any other Minerua.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: I comprehend you sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: I do stand you Sir: fall backe to your first place. Good; passing well: Very properly pursewd.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Beautifull, ambiguous, and sufficient Lady. What are you all alone.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: We would be Sir, if you would leaue vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: I am at your beauties appointment: bright Angell; but—

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: What but?

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: No harme, more then most faire feature.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: Tht touch relished well.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: But I protest.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: And why should you protest?

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: For good will (deare esteem'd Madam) and I hope your Ladiship will so conceiue of it: If euer you haue seene great TAMBERLAINE.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: O that Blanke was excellent: if you could pick out more of these Play-particles, and (as occasion shall salute you) embroyder or damaske your discourse with them (perswade your soule) it would iudiciouslye commend you: Come, this was a well-dischar'gd and auspicious Bout: prooue the se∣cond.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Lady, I cannot swagger it in Black and Yellow.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: Why if you can Reuell it in White Sir, 'tis suffici∣ent.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Say you so Sweete Lady? Lan, tede de, de, dant, dant, dant, dante, &c. No (in good faith) Madame, whoseuer tould your Ladyship so, abus'd you; but I would be glad to meete your Ladiship in a measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Me Sir? beelike you measure me by your selfe then?

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Would I might Fayre Feature.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: And what were you the better, if you might?

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: The better it please you to aske, Fayre Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: Why this was rauishing, and most acutely conti∣new'd; Well, spend not your humor too much, you haue now competently exercised your Conceipt: This (once or twise a day (wil render you an accomplisht, elaborate, and well leueled Gentleman; conuay in your Courting-stock, wee will (in the heate of this) goe visite the Nymphs Chamber.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: I would this water would arriue once our trauayling friend so commended to vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: So would I, for he has left all vs in trauaile, with ex∣pectation of it.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Pray Ioue, I neuer rise from this Couch, if euer I thir∣sted more for a thing, in my whole time of being a Courtier.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Nor I, Ile be sworne; the very mention of it sets my lippes in a worse heate, then if he had sprinkled them with Mercury. Reach me the glasse Sirah.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Heere Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: They do not peele sweete charge? do they?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Yes a little Guardian.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: O 'tis a imminent good signe. Euer when my lippes do so, I am sure to haue some delicious good drinke or other approaching.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Mary & this may be good for vs Ladies: for (it seemes) tis far-fet by their stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: My pallat for yours (deare Honor) it shall prooue most elegant I warrant you: O, I do fancie this geare thats long a comming, with an vnmeasurable strayne.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Pray thee sit downe Philautia, that Rebatu beecoms thee singularly.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Ist not queynt?

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Yes faith: me thinkes thy serunt Hedon is nothing so obsequious to thee, as he was wont to be; I know not how, Hee's growne out of his Garbe a-late, hee's warp't▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: In truenesse, and so me thinkes too, he's much con∣uerted.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Tut; let him bee what he will, 'tis an Animal I dreame not of. This tire (me thinkes) makes me looke very In∣genuously, quick, and spirited: I should be some Laura, or some Delia me thinkes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: As I am wise (faire honors) that title she gaue him, to be her Ambition, spoild him: Before, he was the most propi∣tious, and obseruant young Nouice.—

SP.SPEAKER: Pha,
SP.P: No, no; you are the whole heauen awry Guardian, tis the swaggering tilt-horse Anaides drawes with him there, has beene the diuerter of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: For Cupids sake speake no more of him; would I might neuer dare to looke in a Mirror againe, if I respect ere a Mar∣maset of them all, otherwise, then I would a Fether, or my Shit∣tle-cock, to make sport with, now and then.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Come sit downe; troath (and you be good Beauties) lets run ouer 'hem all now: Which is the properst man amongst them? I say the Trauailer, Amorphus.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: O fie on him: he lookes like a Dutch Trumpetter i'the battell of Lepanto, in the gallery yonder; and speakes to the tune of a country Lady, that comes euer i'the rere ward, or traine of a Fashion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: I should haue iudgement, in a feature sweet Beauties.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: A body would thinke so, at these yeares.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: And I prefer another now, farre before him, A million at least.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Who might that be Guardian?

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: Mary (faire Charge) Anaides.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Anaides? you talk't of a tune Philautia, theres one speakes in a Key: like the opening of some Iustices gate, or a Post-Boyes horne, as if his voyce fear'd an Arrest for some ill words it should giue, and were loath to come forth.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I, and he has a very imperfect face.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Like a squeez'd Orenge, sower, sower.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: His Hand's too great to; by at least a strawes breadth.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Nay he has a woorse fault then that too.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: A long heele?

SP.SPEAKER: Pha▪
SP.P: That were a fault in a Lady rather then him: No, they say he puts of the Calues of his legges with his Stockings eue∣ry night.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Out vpon him: turne to another of the Pictures for Gods sake. What saies Argurion? whom do's she commend a∣fore the rest?

SP.SPEAKER: Cupid.
SP.P: I hope I haue instructed her sufficiently for an an∣swere.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: Troth I made the motion to her Lady-ship for one to day i'the Presence, but it appear'd shee was other wayes fur∣nisht before; She would none.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Who was that Argurion?

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: Mary the little, poore, plaine Gentlemā i'the black there.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Who? Criticus?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: I, I, he; A fellow that no body so much as lookt vpon, or regarded, and she would haue had me done him particuler grace.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: That was a true trick of your selfe Moria, to perswade Argurion affect the scholler.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Tut; but she shalbe no chooser for me. In good faith I like the Citizens sonne there Asotus, mee thinkes, none of them all come neare him.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Not Hedon?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Hedon, in troth no. Hedon's a pretty slight Courtier▪ and he weares his clothes well, and sometimes in fashion; mar∣ry his face is but indifferent, and he has no such excellent bo∣dy. No; th'other is a most delicate youth, a sweete face, a streight body, a well proportion'd legge, and foote, a white hand, a ten∣der voyce.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: How now Argurion?

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: O you should haue let her alone, she was bestowing a Coppy of him vpon vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Why she doates more palpably vpon him, then ere his Father did vpon her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Beleeue me, the young gentleman deserues it; if she could doate more t'were not amisse: He is an exceeding pro∣per youth, and would haue made a most neate Barber-surge∣on, if he had beene put to it in time.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Say you so? me thinkes▪ he lookes like a Taylor already.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: I, that had said on one of his Customers suites.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Wel Ladyes, Iest on: the best of you both would be glad of such a seruant.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: I, Ile be sworne would they: Go to Beauties, make much of Time, and Place, and Occasion, and Opportunity, and Fauorites, and things that belong to them; for Ile ensure you, they will all relinquish; they cannot endure aboue another yeere; I know it out of future experience, and therefore take exhibition, and warning: I was once a Reueller my selfe, and though I speake it (as mine owne Trumpet) I was then esteemd—

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: The very Marchpane of the Court I warrant?

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: And all the Gallants came about you like flies, did they not?

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: Go to; they did somewhat, that's no matter now. Here comes Hedon.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. 2.
DIV2.STAGE: Hedon. Anaides. Mercury. Phantaste. Philautia. Moria. Argurion. Cupid.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Saue you sweete and cleare beauties: By the spirit that mooues in me, you are almost pleasingly bestow'd Ladies. Only, I can take it for no good Omen, to finde mine Honor so deiected.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: You need not feare Sir, I did of purpose humble my selfe against your comming, to decline the pride of my Ambi∣tion.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P:
Fayre Honor, Ambition dares not stoope; but if it be your sweet pleasure, I shall loose that Title; I will (as I am
Hedon) apply my selfe to your bounties.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: That were the next way to distitle my selfe of Honor: O no, rather be still Ambitious I pray you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: I will be any thing that you please, whilst it pleaseth you to be your selfe Lady. Sweete Phantaste, Deare Moria, most beautifull Argurion.—

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Farewell Hedon.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Anaides, Stay: wether go you?

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: 'Slight, what should I do here? and you engrose hem all for your owne vse, 'tis time for me to seeke out.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: I engrose 'hem? Away mischiefe, this is one of your extrauagant Iests now, because I began to salute 'hem by their names—

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Faith you might haue spar'de vs Madame Prudence the Guardian there, though you had more couetously aymde at the rest.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: 'Shart, take 'hem all man; what speake you to me of ayming or Couetous?

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: I, say you so? nay then, haue at 'hem: Ladies, heer's one hath distinguish'd you by your names already; It shall onely become me, to aske; How you doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Gods so, was this the disseigne you trauel'd with?

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Who answers the Brazen head? it spoke to some body?

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Lady Wisedome, do you Interprete for these puppets?

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: In truth, and sadnesse (Honors) you are in great offence for this; goe too, the Gentleman (Ile vndertake with him) is a man of faire liuing, and able to maintaine a Lady in her two Coaches a day, besides Pages, Munkeys, and Parachitos, with stch attendants as she shall thinke meete for her turne; and therefore there is more respect requirable, how soeuer you seeme to conniue: Hearke you Sir, let me discourse a sillable with you. I am to say to you, these Ladyes are not of that close, and open behauiour, as happily you may suspend; their Cari∣adge is well knowne to be such as it should be, both gentle and extraordinary.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr.
SP.P: O here comes the other Payre.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. 3.
DIV2.STAGE: Amorphus. Asotus. Hedon. Anaides. Mercurie. Cupid. Phantaste. Philautia. Argurion. Moria.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: That was your Fathers Loue, the Nymph Argurion. I would haue you direct all your Courtship thither, if you could but endeare your selfe to her affection, you were eternal∣ly engallanted.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: In truth Sir? pray Phoebus I prooue fauorsome in her fayre eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: All diuine mixture, and encrease of beauty, to this bright Buy of Ladyes; and to the male-Courtiers Complement, and Courtesie.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: In the behalfe of the Males, I gratefie you Amorphus.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: And I of the Females.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Succinctly spoken: I doe vale to both your thanks, and kisse them; but primarily to yours, Most ingenious, acute, and polite Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Gods my life, how he do's all to be qualifie her! Inge∣nious, Acute, and Polite? as if there were not others in place, as Ingenious, Acute, and Polite, as she.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Yes, but you must know Lady, he cannot speake out of a Dictionary method.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: Sit downe sweete Amorphus. When will this water come thinke you?

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: It cannot now be long fayre Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Now obserue Mercury.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: How most Ambiguous beauty? Loue you? that I will by this Hand-kercher.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: 'Slid he drawes his oathes out of his pocket.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: But will you be constant?

SP.SPEAKER: Asotus.
SP.P:
Constant Madame? I will not say for Constant∣nesse, but by this Pursse (which I would bee loath to sweare by, vnlesse 'twere embroyder'd)
I protest (more then most fayre Lady) you are the onely, absolute and vn-paraleld Creature, I do adore, and admire, and respect, and reuerence in this Court, Corner of the world, or Kingdome, Me thinkes you are Melancholy.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Do's your heart speake all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Say you?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: O he is groaping for another oath.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Now by this Watch (I marle how forward the day is) I do vnfaignedly vowe my selfe ('Slight 'tis deeper then I tooke it, past fiue) your's entirely addicted, Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: I require no more dearest Asotus, hence-forth let me call you mine; and in remembrance of me, voutchsafe to weare this Chaine, and this Diamond.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: O god sweete Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: There are new oathes for him: what? dooth Hermes taste no Alteration in all this?

SP.SPEAKER: Mr.
SP.P: Yes, thou hast strooke Argurion enamour'd on Aso∣tus methinkes?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Alasse no; I am no body, I: I can do nothing in this disguise.

SP.SPEAKER: Mrcu.
SP.P: But thou hast not wounded any of the rest, Cu∣pid?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Not yet: it is enough that I haue begunne so prospe∣rously.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Tut, these are nothing to the Gems I will howerly bestow vpo thee: be but faithfull and kinde to me, and I will lade thee with my richest bounties: beholde here my Brace∣lets from mine Armes.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Not so good Lady, By this Diamond.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Take 'hem; weare 'hem: my Iewels, Chaine of Pearle, Pendants, all I haue.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Nay then, by this Pearle You make me a Wanton.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Shall not she answere for this, to mainteine him thus in swearing?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: O, no, there is away to weane him from this: the Gentleman may be reclaim'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: I, if you had the ayring of his apparell Cosse, I thinke.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Louing? 'twere pitty I should be liuing else, beleeue me. Saue you Sir. Saue you sweete Lady, Saue you Mounsieur Anaides; Saue you deare Madame.

SP.SPEAKER: Ana.
SP.P: Doo'st thou knowe him that saluted thee, He∣don?

SP.SPEAKER: Hedon.
SP.P: No, some idle Fungoso I warrant you.

SP.SPEAKER: Ana.
SP.P: 'Sbloud, I neuer saw him till this morning, and he sa∣lutes me as familiarly, as if we had knowne together, since the first yeare of the siege of Troy.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: A most right-handed, and auspicious encounter. Confine your selfe to your fortunes.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: For gods sake lets haue some Ridles or Purposes; hough.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: No faith, your Prophecies are best, the 'tother are stale.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Prophecies? wee cannot all it in at them; we shall make a confusion: no; what calde you that we had in the fore∣noone?

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Substantiues, and Adiectiues. Ist not Hedon?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I that, who begins?

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: I haue thought; speake your Adiectiues Sirs?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: But doe not you change then.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Not I, Who sayes?

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: Odoriferous.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Popular.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Humble.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: White-liuer'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Hedon.
SP.P: Barbarous.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Pythagoricall.

SP.SPEAKER: Hedon.
SP.P: Yours Signior.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: What must I doe Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Giue foorth your Adiectiue with the rest; as Pro∣sperous, Good, Faire, Sweete, Well.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Any thing that hath not bin spoken.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Yes Sir: Well-spoken shall be mine.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: What? ha you all doone.

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.P: I.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Then the Substantiue is Breeches. Why Odoriferous Breeches Guardian?

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: Odoriferous, because Odoriferous: that which con∣taines most variety of sauor, and smell, we say is most Odorife∣rous: now Breeches I presume are incident to that variety, and therefore, Odoriferous Breeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Well, we must take it howsoeuer, who's next. Phi∣lautia.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Popular.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Why Popular Breeches?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Mary that is, when they are not content to be gene∣rally noted in Court; but will presse footth on common Sta∣ges, and Brokers stalls, to the publique view of the world.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Good: why Humble Breeches? Argurien.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Humble, because they vse to be sat vpon; besides if you tye 'hem not vp, their propertie is to fall downe about your heeles.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Shee has worne the Breeches it seemes which haue done so.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: But why White-liuerd?

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Why? 'Sharte are not their linings white? besides, when they come in swaggering company, and will pocket vp any thing; may they not properly bee said to bee White-liuerd?

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: O yes, wee cannot deny it. And why Barbarous, Hedon?

SP.SPEAKER: Hedon.
SP.P: Barbarous, because commonly when you haue worn your Breeches sufficiently, you giue them to your Barbar.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: That's good: but now Pythagoricall?

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: I, Amorphus. Why Pythagoricall Breeches?

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: O most kindly of all, 'tis a conceit of that Fortune; I am bould to hug my braine for.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: How ist, Equisite Amorphus?

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: O I am rapt with it, 'tis so fit, so proper, so happy.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Nay doe not rack vs thus?

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: I neuer truly relisht my selfe before. Giue me your eares. Breeches Pythagoricall, by reason of their transmigration into seuerall shapes.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Most rare in sweete troth. Mary this young Gen∣tleman, for his Well-spoken—

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: I, why Well-spoken Breeches?

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Well-spoken: mary well-spoken, because whatso∣euer they speake is well taken, and whatsoeuer is well taken, is well-spoken.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Excellent: beleeue me.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Not so Ladyes neither.

SP.SPEAKER: Hedon.
SP.P: But why Breeches now?

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: Breeches quasi Beare-riches; when a gallant beares all his Ritches in his Breeches.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: In good faith these vnhappy Pages, would be whipt for staying thus.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Beshrew my hand, and my hart else.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: I do wonder at their protraction.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Pray God my whore haue not discouer'd her selfe to the raskally Boyes, and that be the cause of their stay.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: I must sute my selfe with another Page; this idle Pro∣saites will neuer be brought to waite well▪

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: Sir I haue a kinseman I could willingly wish to your seruice, if you would deigne to accept of him.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: And I shalbe glad (most sweet Lady) to imbrace him; where is he?

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: I can fetch him Sir, but I would be loath to make you turne away your other Page.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: You shall not most sufficient Lady, I will keepe both: pray you lets go see him.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Whether goes my Loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Ile returne presently; I go but to see a Page with this Lady.

SP.SPEAKER: Anaid.
SP.P:
As sure as Fate 'tis so; shee ha's opened all: A poxe of all Cocatrices. Damne mee if shee haue playde
loose with me, Ile cut her throate within a hayres bredth, so it may be heald againe.

SP.SPEAKER: Mercu.
SP.P: What is he Iealous of his Hermaphrodite?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: O I, this will be excellent sporte.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Phantaste, Argurion, what? you are sodainly stroake me thinkes; for Gods will lets ha' some Musique till they come. Ambition reach the Lyra I pray you.

SP.SPEAKER: Hedon.
SP.P: Any thing to which my Honor shall direct me.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Come Amorphus; cheare vp Phantaste.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: It shall be my pride faire Lady to attempt all that is in my power. But heere is an Instrument that (alone) is able to infuse soule in the most melancholique, and dull disposde Creature vpon earth; O! let me kisse thy faire knees: Beauteous ares attend it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hedon.
SP.P: Will you haue the Kisse Honor.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I good Ambition.

LG.HEAD: Ode.
LG.L: O That Ioy so soone should wast!
So sugred, so melting, so soft, so delicious,
The dew that lyes on Roses,
When the Morne her selfe discloses,
O, rather then I would it smother,
Were I to taste such another;

SP.SPEAKER: Hedon.
SP.P: I made this Ditty and the Note to it vpon a kisse that my Honor gaue me; how like you it Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: A pretty Ayre; in generall I like it well. But in par∣ticuler, your long die-Note did arride me most, but it was som∣what too long: I can shew one, almost of the same nature, but much before it, and not so long; in a Composition of mine owne: I thinke I haue both the Note, and Ditty about me.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Pray you Sir see.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Yes there is the Note; and all the parts if I mis-thinke not. I will reade the Ditty to your Beauties here, but first I am to make you familiar with the occasion, which presents it selfe thus. Vpon a time, going to take my leaue of the Empe∣rour, and kisse his great handes; there being then present, the Kings of Fraunce, and Arragon, the Dukes of Sauoy, Florence, Orleance, Bourbon, Brunswick, the Lantgrau, Count Palatine, all which had seuerally feasted me; besides infinite more of infe∣riour persons, as Earles, and others: it was my chance (the Em∣perour detain'd by some other affayre) to waite him the fifth part of an houre, or much nere it▪ In which time (retiring my selfe into a Bay-window) I encountred the Lady Annabel neice to the Empresse, and ister to the king of Arragon; who (hauing neuer before ey de me, but onely heard the common report of my Vertue, Learning, and Trauaile) fell into that extremity of passion, for my loue, that she there immediatly sounded: Phisi∣tians were sent for; she had to her chamber; so to her bed; where (languishing some few daies) after many times calling vpon me, with my name in her mouth, she expirde. As that (I must needes say) is the onely fault of my Fortune, that as it hath euer bin my hap to be sew'd to by all Ladies, and Beauties where I haue come; so, I neuer yet soiourn'd, or rested in that place, or part of the world, where some great and admirable faire Creature died not for my loue.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: O the sweete power of trauaile, are you guilty of this Cupid?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: No Mercury; and that his page (Cos) knowes, and he were here present to be sworne.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.L: But how doth this draw on the Ditty Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Mor.
SP.P: O she is to quick with him; he hath not deuis'd that yet.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Marry some houre beefore shee departed, she be∣queath'd to me this Glou; which the Emperour himselfe tooke care to send after me, in sixe Coaches, couer'd all with black-veluet, attended by the state of his Empire; all which he freely gaue me, and I reciprocally (out of the same bounty) gaue it to the Lords that brought it: onely reseruing, and respecting, the gift of the deceasde Lady, vpon which I compos'd this Ode, and set it to my most affected Instrument the Lyra.

LG.HEAD: Ode.
LG.L: THou more then most sweete Gloue,
Suffer me to store, with kisses
This empty lodging, tht now misses
The pure Rosie hand that ware thee,
Whiter then the Kid that bare thee:
Thou art soft, but that was softer;
Cupids selfe hath kist it ofter,
Then ere he did his mothers Doues,
Supposing her the Queene of Loues

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Blasphemy, Blasphemy Cupid.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: I, Ile reuenge it time inough; Hermes.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Good Amorphus, let's here it sung.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: I care not to do that, since it pleaseth Philautia to re∣quest it.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Heere Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Nay play it I pray you, you do well, you do well: how like you it Sir?

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Very well in troath.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: But very well? O you are a meere Mammohrept in iudgement then: why do you not obserue how excellently the Ditty is affected in euery place? that I do not marry a word of short quantity, to a long Note▪ nor an ascending Sillable to a discending Tone. Besides vpon the worde Best there, you see how I do enter with an odde Minnum, and driue it thorough the Briefe, which no intelligent Musitian (I know) but will affirme to bee very rare, extraordinary, and plea∣sing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: And yet not fit to lament the death of a Lady for all this.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Tut heere be they will swallow any thing.

SP.SPEAKER: Phantast.
SP.P: Pray you let mee haue a coppy of it Amor∣phus.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: And me too, in troath I like it exceedingly.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: I haue denyed it to Princes, neuerthelesse to you (the true Female Twinnes of Perfection) I am wonne to depart withall.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: I hope I shall haue my Honors coppy.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: You are Ambitious in that Hedon. Enter Anaides.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: How now Anaides? what is it hath coniur'd vp this distemperature in the circle of your face?

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: 'Sblod what haue you to do? A pox of God o'your filthy trauailing Beard; hold your tongue.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Nay, dost heare mischiefe?

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Away Musk-cat.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: I say to thee: Thou art rude, impudent, course, im∣polisht; a Frapler, and base.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Heart of my father, what a strange alteration has halfe a yeeres haunting of Ordinaries wrought in this fellow? that came with a Tuff-taffata Ierkin to Towne but th'other day, and now hee is turn'd Hercules, hee wants but a Club.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Sir, I will garter my hose with your guttes; and that shall be all.

SP.SPEAKER: Mercur.
SP.P: 'Slid what rare fire workes bee heere? flash, flash.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: What's the matter Hedon? can you tell?

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Nothing but that he lacks mony, & thinkes weel lend him some to be friends.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Come sweete Lady▪ in good truth ile haue it, you shall not deny me; Morus perswade your Aunt I may haue her pic∣ture, by any meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Morus.
SP.P: Yes Sir: good Aunt now, let him haue it; he will vse me the better, if you loue me, do good Aunt.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Well, tell him he shall haue it.

SP.SPEAKER: Morus.
SP.P: Maister, you shall haue it, she saies;

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Shall I? thanke her good Page.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: What has he entertaind the Foole?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: I, heele waite close you shall see, though the Beggr hang off.

SP.SPEAKER: Morus.
SP.P: Aunt my maister thankes you.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Call him hether.

SP.SPEAKER: Morus.
SP.P: Yes: maister.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Yes in very truth, and gaue me this Pursse, and he ha's promis'd me a most fine Dog; which he will haue drawne with my Picture, and desires most vehemently to be knowne to your Ladyshipps.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Call him hether, 'tis good groping such a Gull.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Maister Asotus. Maister Asotus.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: For Gods sake, let me go: you see, I am call'd to the Ladies.

SP.SPEAKER: Argu.
SP.P: Wilt thou forsake me then?

SP.SPEAKER: Asotus,
SP.P: Gods so, what would you haue mee doe?

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Come hither maister Asotus; I do ensure your La∣dyships, he is a Gentleman of a very worthy desart; and of a most ountiull nature. You must shew and insinuate your selfe responsible, and equiualent now to my commendment. Good Honors grace him.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: I protest (more then most faire Ladyes) I doe wish all variety of diuine plesure, choyse sport, sweete Musique, ritch Fare, braue Ayres, soft Beds, and silken Thoughts, attend these fayre Beauties. Will it please your Ladyship to weare this Chaine of Pearle, and this Diamond for my sake.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: O.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: And you Madam this Iewell, and Pendants.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: O.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: We know not how to deserue these bounties out of so slight merrit, Asotus.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: No in faith, but the'rs my Gloue for a fauor.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: And soone after the Reuels I will bestowe a Garter on you.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: O Lord Ladyes, it is more grace then euer I could haue hop'd, but that it pleaseth your Ladyships to extend; I protest it is enough that you but take knowledge of my—if your Ladiships want embroydered Gownes, Tyres of any Fashion, Rebatus, Iewels, or Carkanets, any thing what soeuer; if you vouchsafe to accept.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: And for it they will helpe you to Shoo-tyes, and de∣uises.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: I cannot vtter my selfe (Deare Beauties) but; you can conceiue—

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: O.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
Hedon.
SP.P: O God Madams, how shall I deserue this? if I were but made acquainted with Hedon now; Ile trye: pray you a∣way.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: How he prayes Money to go away from him.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Amorphus, a word with you: heeres a Watch I would bestowe vpon you, pray you make mee knowne to that Gal∣lant.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: That I will Sir. Mounsieur Hedon I must intreate you to exchange knowledge with this Gentleman.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: 'Tis a thing (next to the water we expect) I thirste after Sir. Good Mounsieur Asotus.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Good Mounsieur Hedon, I would be glad to bee lou'd of men of your Ranke, and spirit, I protest. Please you to accept this payre of Bracelets Sir, they are not worth the bestowing.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: O Hercules; how the Gentleman purchases? this must needes bring Argurion to a consumption.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Sir, I shall neuer stand in the merit of such Bounty. I feare.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: O Lord Sir; your acquaintance shall be sufficient. And if at any time you neede my Bill or my Bond.

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: O, O.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Helpe the Lady there.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Gods deare, Argurion. Madam, how do you?

SP.SPEAKER: Arg.
SP.P: Sicke.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: Haue her foorth and giue her ayre.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: I come againe streight Ladyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Well, I doubt all the Phisique he ha's, will scarce re∣couer her; shee's too farre spent.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. 4.
DIV2.STAGE: Anaides. Gelaia. Cos. Prosaites. Philautia. Phantaste. Moria. Amorphus▪ Hedon.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: O heer's the Water come: fetche Glasses Page.

SP.SPEAKER: Gelaia.
SP.P:
Heart of my body heeres a coyle indeed with your ealous humors. Nothing but Whore, and Bitch, and all the
villanous swaggering names you can thinke on? 'Slid take your Bottle, and put it in your guttes or me, Ile see you poxt ere I follow you any longer?

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Nay good Punke, sweete Rascall; damne me if I am Iealous now.

SP.SPEAKER: Gelaia.
SP.P: That's true indeed, pray lets goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: What's the matter there?

SP.SPEAKER: Gelaia.
SP.P: Slight he has me vpon Intergatories, (nay my Mo∣ther shall know how you vse me) where I haue beene? and why I should stay so long? and how ist possible? and with-all calles me at his pleasure; I knowe not how many Cocatrices, and things.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: In truth and sadnesse, these are no good Epithites

SP.SPEAKER: Anaides:
SP.P: to bestow vpon any Gentlewoman; and (Ile ensure you) if I had knowne you would haue dealt thus with my Daughter, she should neuer haue fancied you so deeply, as she has doone. Goe too.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Why doe you here Mother Moria. Heart.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Nay I pray you Sir doe not sweare.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Sweare? why? Sblood I haue sworne afore now I hope. Both you and your daughter mistake me; I haue not honor'd Arete that is helde the worthyest Lady in the Court (next to Cynthia) with halfe that obseruance and respect, as I haue doone her in priuate, howsoeuer outwardly I haue ca∣ried my selfe carelesse and negligent. Come you are a foolish Punke, and know not when you are well employde. Kisse me. Come on. Do it I say.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Nay, indeed I must confesse she is apt too mispri∣sion. But I must haue you leaue it Minion.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: How now Asotus? how do's the Lady?

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Fayth ill. I haue left my Page with her at her lodging.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: O heer's the rarest Water that euer was tasted; fill him some.

SP.SPEAKER: Prosai.
SP.P: What? has my Maister a new Page?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Yes a kinsman of the Lady Morias: you must waite better now, or you are casheer'd Prosaites.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Come Gallants; you must pardon my foolish humor, when I am angry, that any thing crosses me, I grow impatient streight. Here I drinke to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi
SP.P: O that we had fiue or sixe Bottles more of this liquor.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Now I commend your iudgement Amorphus: who's that knockes? looke Page.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: O most delicious, a little of this would make Arguri∣on well.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: O no giue her no colde drinke by any meanes.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Sblood, this water is the spirit of Wine, Ile be hangd lse.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Heeres the Lady Arete Madam.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. 5.
DIV2.STAGE: Arete. Phantaste. Philautia. Moria. Anaides. Gelaia. Cos. Prosaites. Amorphus. Asotus. Hedon. Mercury. Cupid.

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.P: What at your Beuer Gallants?

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Wilt please your Lady-shipp drinke, tis of the new fountaine water.

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.P: Not I, Moria; I thanke you: Gallants you must pro∣uide for some solemne Reuels to night, Cynthia is minded to come foorth, and grace your sports with her presence; therefore I could wish there were some thing extraordinary to enter∣taine her.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: What say you to a Masque?

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Nothing better, if the Inuention or Proiect were new and rare.

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.P: Why, Ile send for Criticus, and haue his aduise; you will be ready in your indeuours;

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Yes▪ but will not your Lady-ship stay?

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.P: Not now Phantaste.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Let her go, I pray you; good Lady Sobriety, I am glad we are rid of her.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: What a set Face the gentlewoman has, as she were still going to a Sacrifice?

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: O shee is the extraction of a dozen of Puritans, for a looke.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria
SP.P: Of all Nimphs 'ihe Court I cannot away with her: 'tis the coursest thing—

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: I wounder how Cynthia can affect her so aboue the rest! Heere be they are euery way as faire as she, and a thought, fayrer, I trow.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: I, and as ingenious, and conceipted as she.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: I and as politique as she, for all she sets such a Fore∣head on't.

SP.SPEAKER: Phi.
SP.P: Would I were dead if I would change to bee Cyn∣thia.

SP.SPEAKER: Pha.
SP.P: Or I.

SP.SPEAKER: Moria.
SP.P: Or I.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: And there's her Minion Criticus; why his aduise more then Amorphus? haue I not Inuention, afore him? Learning, to better that Inuention, aboue him? and Tra∣uaile.—

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Death, what talke you of his Learning? he vnder∣stands no more then a schoole-Boy; I haue put him downe my selfe a thousand times (by this Ayre) and yet I neuer talkt with him but twise in my life; you neuer saw his like: I could neuer get him to argue with me, but once, and then because I could not construe a peece of Horace at first sighte, he went awaye and laught at mee. By Gods will, I scorne him, as I do the sodden Nimph that was heere euen now; his mistris Arete: And I loue my selfe for nothing else.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: I wonder the Fellow de's not hang himselfe, being thus scorn'd, and contemn'd of vs that are held the most ac∣complisht Society of Gallants!

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: By your selues none else.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P:
I protest, if I had no Musique in me, no Courtship;
that I were not a Reueller and could daunce, or had not those excellent qualities that giue a man Life, and Perfection, but a meere poore Scholler as he is, I thinke I should make some desperate way with my selfe; whereas now (would I might neuer breath more) if I do know that Creature in this kingdome, with whome I would change.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: This is excellent: well I must alter this soone.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Looke you do Cupid.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: O I shall tickle it soone; I did neuer appeare till then. Slid I am the netliest-made Gallant i'the company, & haue the best presence; and my dauncing—I know what the Vsher saide to me the last time I was at the schoole; would I might leade Philautia in the measure, and 'tweere gods will. I am most worthy, I am sure.

SP.SPEAKER: Morus.
SP.P: Maister I can tell you newes, the Lady kist me yon∣der, and plaid with me; and sayes she lou'd you once, as well as she do's me, but that you cast her of.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Peace my most esteemed Page.

SP.SPEAKER: Morus.
SP.P: Yes.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Gallants, thinke vpon your Time, and take it by the forehead; Anaides, we must mixe this gentleman with you in acquaintance. Mounsieur Asotus.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: I am easily intreated to grace any of your friends, A∣morphus.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Sir, and his friends shall likewise grace you Sir. Nay I begin to know my selfe now.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: O, you must continue your Bounties.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P: Must I? why ile giue him this Ruby on my fin∣ger.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Come Ladies; but stay we shall want one to Lady it in our Masque in place of Argurion.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: Why my page shall do it, Gelaia.

SP.SPEAKER: Hd.
SP.P: Troth and he'e do it well, it shalbe so.

SP.SPEAKER: Asot.
SP.P:
Do you heere Sir, I do hartely wish your acquain∣tance, and I partly know my selfe worthy of it; please you Sir, to accept this poore Ruby in a Ring Sir. The Poeie is of my
owne deuise▪ Let this blush for me Sir.

SP.SPEAKER: Anai.
SP.P: So it must for me, too. For I am not asham'd to take it.

SP.SPEAKER: Morus.
SP.P: Sweete man, by my troath maister I loue you; will you loue me to? for my Aunts sake? Ile waite well you shall see, Ile still be heere. Would I might neuer stirre, but you are in gay clothes.

SP.SPEAKER: Ast.
SP.P: As for that Morus, thou shalt see more here after, in the meane time, by this Aye, or by this Fether, ile do as much for thee as any Galant shall do for his Page whatsoeuer, in this Court, corner of the world, or Kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mercury.
SP.P: I wounder this gentleman should affect to keepe a oole, mee thinkes he makes sport enough with him selfe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Well Prosaites tweere good you did waite closer.

SP.SPEAKER: Pro.
SP.P: I, Ile looke to it; 'tis time.

SP.SPEAKER: Cos.
SP.P: Wee are like to haue sumptuous Reuells to night Sirs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: We must needes when all the choisest Singularities of the Court are vp in Pantofles, nere a one of them, but is able to make a whole shew of it sele.

SP.SPEAKER: Hed.
SP.P: Sirah a Torch, a torch.

SP.SPEAKER: Mercury.
SP.P: O what a call is there? I will haue a Canznet made with nothing in it but ; and the Burthen shalbe. I come.

SP.SPEAKER: Crit.
SP.L: —.A masque, bright Aret
Why tweere a labour more for Hercules.
Better, and sooner durst I vndertake:
To make the different seasons of the Yeere,
The Windes, or Elements to sympathize;
Then their vnmeasurable vanity
Daunce truely in a measure: They agree?
What though all Concord's borne of Contraries?
So many Follies will confusion prooue▪
And like a sort of iarring Instruments,
All out of tune; because (indeed) we see
There is not that Analogy twixt Discords,
As betweene things but meerely opposite.

SP.SPEAKER: Aret.
SP.L: There is your error; for as Hmes wande
Charmes the disorders, of tumultuous Ghosts,
And as the strife of Chaos then did cease,
When better light then Natures did arriue;
So, what could neuer in it selfe agree,
Forgetteth the eccentrick property,
And at her sight turnes foorthwith regular,
Whose scepter guides the flowing Ocean:
And though it did not, yet the most of them
(Being eyther Courtiers, or not wholy rude)
Respect of Maiesty, the Place, and Presnce,
Will kepe them within Ring; especially
When they are not presented as themselues,
But masqu'd like others: for (in troth) not so
T'incorporate them, could be nothing else
Then like a State vngouern'd, without lawes; or
A body made of nothing but diseases;
The one, through impotencie poore, and wretched;
The other for the Anarchy absurd.

SP.SPEAKER: Crit.
SP.L: But Lady, for the Reuellers themselues;
It would be better (in my poore conceipt,)
That others were imploy'd; for such as are
Vnfit to be in Cynthias Court, can seeme
No lese vnfit to be in Cynthias sports.

SP.SPEAKER: Aret.
SP.L: That is not done (my Criticus) without
Particular knowledge of the Goddesse minde;
Who (holding true intelligence, what Follyes
Had crept into her Pallace) she resolu'd,
Of sports, and Triumphs; vnder that pretext,
To haue them muster in their Pompe and Fulnesse:
That so she might more strictly, and to roote,
Effect the Reformation she intends.

SP.SPEAKER: Crit.
SP.L: I now conceiue her heauenly drift in all;
And will apply my spirits to serue thy will:
O thou, the very power by which I am;
And but for which, it were in vaine to be;
Chiefe next Diana, Virgin, heauenly fayre▪
Admired Arete, (of them admir'd
Whose soules are not enkindled by the sence)
Disdeigne not my chast fire, but feed the flame
Deuoted truely to thy gracious name.

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.L: Leaue to suspect vs: Criticus shall finde
As we are now most deare, weele prooue most kinde.

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.L: Harke, I am cald.

SP.SPEAKER: Crit.
SP.L: I follow instantly,
Phoebus Apollo: if with ancient Rites,
And due Deuotions, I haue euer hung
Elaborate Paeans on thy golden Shrine,
Or sung thy Triumphs in a lofty straine;
Fit for a Theater of Gods to heare:)
And thou the other sonne of mighty Io
Cyllenian Mercury (sweete Maias ioye)
If in the busie tumults of the minde,
My path thou euer hast illumined:
For which, thine Altars I haue oft perum'de,
And deckt thy Statue with discoulored flowers:
Now thriue Inuention in this glorious Court,
That not of bounty only, but of right,
Cynthia may grace, and giue it life by sight.

DIV2.HEAD: SCENA. 1.
DIV2.STAGE: Hesperus. Cynthia. Arete. TymE. Phronesis. Thauma.

LG.L: QVeene and Huntresse, chaste, and fayre,
Now the Sunne is layde to sleepe,
Earth, let not thy enuious shade
Cynthias shining Or be was made
Heauen to cleare, when day did close:
Blesse vs then with wished sight,
Lay thy Bowe of Pearle apart.
Space to breath, how short soeuer.
Thou, that makst a day of night,

SP.SPEAKER: Cnt.
SP.L: When hath Diana, like an enuious wretch▪
That glitters onely to his soothed selfe,
Denying to the world the precious ve
Of hoorded wealth, with-held her friendly ayde?
Mon'thly we spend our still-repaired shine,
And not forbid our Virgin-waxen torch,
To burne, and blaze while nutriment doth last:
That once consum'd, out of Ioues treasury
Anew we take, and stick it in our Spheare
To giue the mutinous kinde of wanting men,
Their lookt for light. Yet what is their desert?
" Bounty is wrongd, interpreted as due;
" Mortalls can chalenge not a Ray but right,
" Yet do exspect the whole of Cynthias light:
But if that Deities with-drew their guifts,
For humane Follies, what should men deserue
But Death and Darknesse? It behooes the high,
For their owne sakes to do things worthely.

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.L: Most true, most sacred goddesse; for the Heauens
Receiue no good of all the good they do:
Nor Ioue, nor you, nor other heauenly Power,
Are fed with Fumes, which do from Incense rise,
Or Sacrifices reeking in their gore:
Yet for the care which you of mortalls haue,
(Whose proper Good it is, that they be so;)
You well are pleas'd with Odours redolent:
But ignorant is all the Race of men,
Which still complaines, not knowing why, or when,

SP.SPEAKER: Cyn.
SP.L: Else noble Arete, they would notblame,
And taxe for or vniust, or for as proud
Thy Cynthia, in the things which are indeed
The greatest glories in our starry crowne:
Such is our Chastity, which safely scornes,
Not Loue (for who more feruently doth loue
Immortall Honor, and diuine Renowne?)
But giddy Cupid, Venus frantick sonne.
Yet Arete, if by this vayled light
We but discouer'd (what we not discerne)
Any the least of imputations, stand
Ready to sprinkle our vnspotted fame,
With note of lightnesse, from these Reuels neare:
Not, for the Empire of the Vniuerse
Should Night or Court, this whatsoeuer shine
Or grace of ours, vnhappely enioy.
" Place, and Occsion are two priuy Thieues;
" And from poore innocent Ladies, often steale
" (The best of things) an honourable Name:
" To stay with Follyes, or where Faults may be,
" Infers a Crime, although the party free.

SP.SPEAKER: Aret.
SP.L: How Cynthianly (that is how worthely
And like her selfe) the matchlesse Cynthia speakes!
Infinite Iealousies, infinite Reguards,
Do watch about the true virginity:
But Phoebe liues from all not onely fault,
But as from thought, so from suspicion free,
" Thy Presence broad-seales our delights for pure,
" What's done in Cynthias sight, is done secure.

SP.SPEAKER: Cynt.
SP.L: That then so answer'd (Dearest Arete)
What th' Argument, or of what sort, our Sports
Are like to be this night; I not demaund.
Nothing which Duty, and desire to please
Beares written in the forhead, comes amiss;
But vnto whose Inuention, must we owe,
The complement of this nights furniture?

SP.SPEAKER: Aret.
SP.L: Excellent Goddesse, to mans, whose worth,
(Without Hyperbole,) I thus may praise;
One (at least) studious, of deseruing well:
And (to speake truth) indeed deseruing well,
" Potentiall merit stands for actuall,
" Where only Opportunity dooth want,
" Not Will, nor Power: both which in him abound.
One whom the Muses, and Minerua loue;
For whom should they more loue then Criticus,
Whom Phoebus (though not Fortune) holdeth deare?
And (which conuinceth excellence in him▪)
A principall admirer of your selfe:
Euen▪ through th'vngentle iniuries of Fate,
And difficulties, which do vertue choake,
Thus much of him appeares. What other things
Of farther note, do lye vnborne in him,
Them I do leaue for cherishment to shew.
And for a Goddesse graciously to iudge.

SP.SPEAKER: Cynt.
SP.L: We haue already iudg'd him Arete:
Nor are we ignorant, how noble mindes
Suffer too much through those indignities,
Which Times, and vicious Persons cast on them:
Our selfe haue euer vowed to esteeme
(As Vertue, for it selfe) so Fortune, base;
Who first in Worth, the same be first in Place.
Nor farther notice (Arete) we craue
Then thine approualls soueraigne warranty:
Let, be thy care, to make vs knowne to him;
" Cynthia shall brighten what the World made dim▪

SP.SPEAKER: Ante.
SP.P:
Cleare Pearle of Heauen, and not to be farther ambitious in titles) Cynthia. The fame of this illustrious night, among others hath also drawne these foure faire Virgins from the Pallace of their Queene Perfection (a word, which makes no sufficient difference, twixt hers, and thine) to visit thy Imperiall Court: for she their Soue∣raigne Lady, not finding where to dwel among men, before her teturne to heauen: aduised them wholy to consecrate themselues to thy Coele∣stiall seruice, as in whose cleare Spirit (the proper Element, and Sphare of vertues) they should behould not her alone, (their euer honor'd Mistresse) but themselues) more truely themselues) to liue en∣thronised.
Her selfe would haue commended them vnt thy fauour more particularly, but that she knowes no commendation is more auail∣able with thee then that of proper vertue: Neuerthelesse, she wilde them to present this Christall Mound, a note of Monarchy, and Symbole of Perfection, to thy more worthy Deity; which as heere by me they most humbly do, so amongst the Rarities thereof, that is the chiefe, to shew whatsoeuer the world hath excellent, howsoeuer re∣mote and various. But your irradiate iudgement will soone disco∣uer the secrets of this little Christall world. Themselues (to appeare the more plainly) because they know nothing more odious then false pretexts: haue chosen to expresse their seuerall qualities thus in seue∣rall coulors.

1 The first in Citron coullour is naturall Affection, which giuen vs to procure our good, is sometime called Storge, and as euery one is neerest to himselfe, so this Hand-maid of Reason, allowable Selfe-loue, as it is without harme, so are none without it: Her place in the Court of Perfection was to quicken mindes in the pursute of Honor. Her deuice is a Perpendicular Leuell vpon a▪ Cube or Square. The word, SE SVO MODVLO: alluding to that true measure of ones selfe, which as euery one ought to make, so is it most conspicuous in thy diuine example.

2 The second in Greene is Aglaia, delectable and pleasant Con∣uersation, whose property it is to mooue a kindly delight, and sometime not without laughter: Her office to entertaine assemblies, and keepe societies together with fayre familliarity. Her deuice within a Ring of clouds, a Heart with shine about it, the worde, CVRARVM NVBILA PELLO. An Allegory of Cynthias light, which no lesse cleares the Skie, then her ayre Mrthe the heart.

3 The third, in discoulur'd Mantle spangled all ouer, is Eu∣phantaste, a well conceited Wittinesse, and imployde in honouring the Courte with the ritches of her pure Inuention. Her deuice vpon a Petasus, or Mernriall Hat, a Crescent. The worde; SIC LAVS INGENII: Inferring that the praise and glory of
wit, doth euer increase, as dooth thy growing Moone.

4 The fourth in White is Apheleia, a Nymph as pure and s∣ple as the Soule, or as an abrase Table, and is therefore called Sympli∣city; without foulds, without pleights, without coullour, without coun∣terfeit: and (to speake plainely) Plainenesse it selfe. Her deuice is no De∣uice. The word vnder her siluer Shield: OMNIS ABEST FVCVS, alluding to thy spotlesse selfe, who art as farre from Impu∣rity, as from Mortality.

My selfe (Coelestiall Goddesse) more fit for the Court of Cyn∣thia, then the Arbors of Cythere, am call'd Anteros, or Loues ene∣my; the more welcome therefore to thy Court, and the fitter to conduct this Quaternio, who as they are thy professed Votaries, and for that cause aduersaries to Loue, yet thee (Perpetuall Virgin) they both loue, and vow to loue eternally.

SP.SPEAKER: Cynthia.
SP.L: Not without wounder, nor with out delight,
Mine eyes haue veiwd in Contemplations depth,
This worke of wit, diuine, and excellent:
What Shape? what Substance? or what vnknowne Power
In virgins habit crown'd with Lawrell leaues
And Oliue branches wouen in betweene,
On Sea-girt Rocke like to a Goddesse shins?
O front! O face! O all celestiall sure
And more then mortall! Arete, behould
Another Cynthia, and another Queene,
Whose glory (like a lasting Plenilun)
Seems ignorant of what it is to wane.
Not vnder heauen an Obiect could be found
More fit to please; let Criticus approach,
Bounty forbids to paull our thankes with stay,
Or to deferre our fauour after view:
" The time of Grace is, when the Cause is new.

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.L: Lo heere the man (coelestiall Delia)
Who (like a Circle bounded in it selfe,)
Containes asmuch, as Man in fulnesse may.
Lo here the man; who, not of vsuall earth,
But of that nobler, and more precious mould
Which Phoebus selfe doth temper, is compos'd;
And, who (though all were wanting to reward,
Yet, to himselfe he would not wanting be:
Thy Fauors gaine is his Ambitions most,
And labours best; who (humble in his height)
Stands fixed silent in thy glorious sight.

SP.SPEAKER: Cynthia.
SP.L: With no lesse pleasure, then we haue beheld,
This pretious Christall, worke of rarest wit,
Our eye doth reade thee, now, our Criticus;
Whom Learning, Vertue, and our Fauour last,
Exempteth from the gloomy Multitude.
" With common eye the Supreme should not see.
Hence forth be ours, the more thy selfe to be.

SP.SPEAKER: Crit.
SP.L: Heauens purest light, whose Orbe may be eclips'd,
But not thy Praise; (diuinest Cynthia)
How much too narrow for so high a grace,
Thy (saue therein) vnworthy Criticus:
Doth finde himselfe? for euer shine thy Fame;
Thine Honours euer, as thy Beauties do;
In me they must, my darke worldes chiefest Lights;
By whose propitious beames my powres are rais'd
To hope some part of those most lofty points,
Which blessed Arete hath pleas'd to name
As markes, which my'ndeuors steps should bend:
Mine, as begunne at thee, in thee must end.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Sister of Phoebus to whose bright Orbe we owe, that we not complaine of his Absence; These foure Brethren (for they are Brethrē and sonnes of Eutaxia, a Lady knowne, and highly belou'd of your resplendent Deity) not able to be absent, when Cynthia held a solemp∣nity, officiously insinuate themselues into thy presence: For as there are foure Cardinall vertues, vpon which the whole Frame of the Cour dooth mooue, so are these the foure Cardinall properties without which the Body of Complement mooueth not. With those foure siluer Iauelins (which they beare in their hands) they support in Princes Courts the state of the Presence, as by office they are obliged; which though heere they may seeme superfluous, yet for Honors sake they thus presume to visite thee, hauing also bin imployde in the Pallace of Queene Per∣fection. And though to them, that would make themselues gratious to a Goddesse, Sacrifices were fitter then Presents or Impresses, yet they both hope thy fauor, and (in place of eyther) vse seuerall Sym∣boles containing the titles of thy imperiall Dignity.

1 The hit hermost in the changeable blew, and greene Roabe, is the commendably-fashionate Gallant Eucosmos; whose Courtly Ha∣it is the grace of the Presence, and delight of the surueying eye: whom Ladies vnderstand by the names of Neate, & Elegant. His Symbol is DIVAE VIRGINI, in which he would expresse thy Dei∣ties principall glory, which hath euer bin Virginity.

2 The second in the ritch Acoutrement, and Roabe of Purple empaled with Gold, is Eupathes; who intertaines his minde with an harmlesse, but not incurious variety: All the Obiects of his sences are Sumptuous, himselfe a Gallant, that without excesse can make vse of superfluities: goe ritchly in Imbroyders, Iewels, (and what not?) with∣out Vanity; and fare delicately without Gluttony: and therefore (not without cause) is vniuersally thought to be of fine humor. His Sym∣bole
is DIVAE OPTIMAE. An attribute to expresse thy Goodnesse in which thou so resemblest loue thy father.

3. The third in the blush-collourd Sute is Eutolmos, as duly respecting others, as neuer neglecting himselfe; commonly knowne by the title of Good Audacitie, to Courts and courtly assemblies, a guest most acceptable. His Simbole is DIVAE VIRAGINI, To expresse thy hardy Courage, in chase of Sauage beasts which har∣bor in Woods, and Wildernesse.

4. The fourth in Watchet-Tinsell, is the kinde, and truly Be∣nefique Eucolos. Who imparteth not without respect, but yet without difficulty: and hath the happinesse to make euery kindnesse seeme dou∣ble, by the timely, and freely bestowing thereof, he is the chiefe of them who (by the vulgar) are said to be of Good Nature. His Symbole is DIVAE MAXIMAE. An Adiunct to signifie thy great∣nesse, which in heauen, earth, and hell is formidable.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Is not that Amorphus the Traueller?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: As though it were not? do you not see how his legges are in trauaile with a Measure?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Hedon, thy maister is next.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: What will Cupid turne Nomenclator, and cry them?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: No faith, but I haue a Comedy toward, that would not be lost for a kingdome.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: In good time, for Cupid will prooue the Comedy.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Mercury, I am studying how to match them.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: How too mismatch them, were harder.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: It is the Nymphes must do it, I shall sport my selfe with their passions aboue measure.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Those Nymphes would be tam'd a little indeed, but I feare thou hast not Arrowes for the purpose.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: O yes, here be of all sorts, Flightes, Rouers, and But∣shafts. But I can wound with a Brandish, and neuer draw Bow for the matter.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: I cannot but beleeue it my inuisible Archer, and yet me thinkes you are tedious.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup:
SP.P: It behoues me to be somewhat circumspect Mercury, for if Cynthia here the twange of my Bow, sneele go neare to whip me with the string; therefore to preuent that, I thus dis∣charge a Brandish vpon—it makes no matter which of the couples: Phantaste, and Amorphus at you.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Will the shaking of a shaft, strike'hem into such a Fe∣uer of Affection?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: As well as the winke of an Eye: but I pray thee hinder me not with thy prattle.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Ioue forbid I hinder thee. Marry all that I feare is Cyn∣thias presence, which with the could of her Chastey, casteth such an Antiperistasis about the place, that no heate of thine will tarry with the Patient.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: It wiltarry the rather, for the Antiperistasis wil keep it in.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: I long to see the experiment.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Why their marrow boyles already, or they are all turnd Eunuchs.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Nay and't be so, Ile giue ouerspeaking, & be a Specta∣tor onely.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: Cynthia (by my bright soule) is a right exquisite, and spendidious Lady; yet Amorphus I thinke hath seene more fa∣shions, I am sure more Countries; but whether I haue or no: what need we gaze on Cynthia, that haue our selfe to admire?

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: O excellent Cynthia; yet if Phantaste sat where shee do's, and had such a tyre on her head (for attire can do much) I say no more; but Goddesses are Goddesses, and Phantaste is as she is. I would the Ruls were done once, I might goe to my Schoole of Glasse againe, and learne to do my selfe right after all this Ruffling.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: How now Cupid? heer's a wonderfull change with your Brandish? do you not heare, how they doate?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: What Prodigie is this? no Word of Loue? no Mention? no Motion?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Not a word my little Hll-fire, not a worde.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Are my Darts enchanted? is their vigor gone? is their vertue—

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: What? Cupid turn'd iealous of himselfe? ha, ha, ha.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Laughes Mercury?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Is Cupid angry?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Hath he not cause, when his purpose is so deluded?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: A rare Comedy, it shall be intitled; Cupids.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Doe not scorne vs Hermes.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Chollar and Cupid are two fiery things; I scorne 'hem not. But I see that come to passe which I presag'd in the be∣ginning.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: You cannot tell: perhaps the Phisicke will not worke so soone vpon some, as vpon others. It may be the Rest are not so resty.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Ex vngue, you know the olde Adage; as these, so are the remainder.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Ile trye: this is the same Shafte with which I woun∣ded Argurion.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: I, but let me saue you a labour Cupid: there were cer∣taine Bottles of Water fetcht, and drunke off, (since that time,) by these Gallants.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Ioue strike me into earth: The Fountaine of Selfe-loue?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Nay faint not Cupid.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: I remembred it not.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Faith it was omenous to take the name of Anteros vpō you, you know not what Charme or Inchantment lyes in the worde: you saw I durst not venter vpon any Deuise in our presentment: but was content to be no other then a simple Page. Your Arrowes properties (to keepe decoum) Cupid, are suted (it should seeme) to the nature of him you personate.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: Indignity not to be borne.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr.
SP.P: Nay rather an attempt to haue bin forborne.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: How might I reuenge my selfe on this insulting Mer∣cury? ther's Criticus his Minnion: he has not tasted of this wa∣ter? it shall be so.
Is Criticus turn'd Dotard on himselfe too?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: That followes not, because the venome of your shats cannot pierce him.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: As though there were one Antidote for these, & another for him?

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: As though there were not? or as if one Effect might not arise of diuerse causes? what say you to Cynthia, Arete, Phronesis Tim E, and others there?

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: They are diuine.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr.
SP.P: And Criticus aspires to be so.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: But that shall not serue him.

SP.SPEAKER: Mr.
SP.P: Tis like to do prettily well at this time. But Cupid is growne too couetous, that will not spare one of a Multitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Cup.
SP.P: One is more then a Multitude.

SP.SPEAKER: Mer.
SP.P: Aretes fauour makes any one shot proofe against thee Cupid.
I pray thee light Hony-Bee, remember thou art not now in Adonis garden, but in Cynthias presence, where thornes garrison about the Roses. Soft Cynthia speakes.

SP.SPEAKER: Cynthia.
SP.L: Ladyes and gallants,
To giue a timely period to our sports,
Let vs conclude them, with declining night;
Our Empire is but of the darker halfe:
And if you iudge it any recompence▪
For your faire paines, t'haue earnd Dias thanks;
Diana grants them: and bestowes their crowne
To gratefie your acceptable Zeale.
For you are they, that not (as some haue done)
Do censure vs, as too seuere, and sower,
But as (more rightly) Gratious to the Good;
Although we not deny, vnto the Proud,
Or the Prophane, perhaps indeed austere:
For so Actaeon by presuming farre,
Did (to our griefe) incurre a fatall doome;
And so, swolne Niob (comparing more
Then he presum'd) was trophaeed into stone.
But are we therefore iudged too extreame?
Seemes it no Crime to er sacred Bowers,
And hallowed Places with impure aspect
Most lewdly to pollute? Seemes it no crime,
To braue a Deity? let Mortalls learne
To make Religion of offending Heauen;
And not at all to censure powers diuine:
To Men, this Argument should stand for firme,
" A Goddesse did it; therefore it was good:
" We are not cruell, nor delight in blood.
But what haue serious Repetitions
To do with Reuels, and the sports of Court?
We not intend to sowre your late delights
With harsh expostulation; Let suffice
That we take notice, and can take reuenge
Of these calumnious, and lewd Blasphemies;
For we are no lesse Cynthia, then we were,
Nor is our Power (but as our Selfe) the same:
Though we haue now put on no tyre of shine
But mortall eyes vndazled may endure.
" Yeares, are beneath the Sphears; and Time makes weake,
" Things vnder Heauen; not Powers which gouerne Heauen:
And though our Selfe be in our selfe, secure,
Yet let not mortalls challenge to themselues
Immunity from thence; Loe this is all:
" Honor hath store of spleene, but wanteth Gall.
Once more, we cast the slumber of our thankes
On your tane toyle, which here let take an end:
And that we not mistake your seuerall worths▪
Nor you our Fauour; from your selues remooue,
What makes you not your selues; those clouds of Masque:
" Particular paines, particular thankes do aske.
—Are we contemn'd?
Is there so little awe of our Disdeigne,
That any (vnder trust of their disguise)
Should mixe themselues with others of the Court?
And (without forhead) bouldly presse so farre▪
As farther none? apt is Lenity
To be abusd? Seurity to be loath'd?
And yet, how much more dooth the seming Face
Of neighbor Vertues, and their borrowed Names,
Adde of lewd Bouldnesse to loose Vanities?
Who would han thought that Philautia durst,
Or haue vsurped noble Storge's name?
Or with that theft haue ventred on our eyes?
Who would haue thought that all of them should hope,
So much of our conniuence, as to come
To grace themselues, with Titles not their owne?
Insteed of Medicines haue we Maladies?
And such Impostumes, as Phantaste is,
Grow in our Pallace? we must lance these sores,
Or all will putrifie: Nor are these all,
For we suspect a farder fraud then this;
Take off our vaile, that shadows may depart,
And shapes appeare, beloued Arete. So.
Another Face of things presents it selfe
Then did of late: what? Featherd Cupid masqu'd?
And masqu'd like to Anteros? but, more strange!
Deare Mercury our Brother, like a Page,
To countenance the ambush of the Boy?
Nor endeth our discouery as yet;
Gelaia like a Nymph, that but ere while
(In male attire,) did serue Anaides?
Cupid came hether to finde sport and Game,
Who, heeretofore hath beene too conuersant
Among our traine; but neuer felt Reuenge:
And Mercury bare Cupid company:
Cupid, we must confesse this Time of mirth
(Proclaimd by vs) gaue Opportunity,
To thy attempts, although no Priuiledge;
Tempt vs no farther, we cannot endure
Thy presence longer: Vanish, Hence, Away.
You Mercury, we must intreate to stay,
And heare what we determine of the rest;
For in this Plot, you haue the deepest hand:
But (for we meane not a Censorian tasque
And yet to lance these vlcers growne so ripe)
Deare Arete, and Criticus, to you
Wee giue the charge; Impose what paines you please:
Th'incurable cut of, the rest reforme;
Remembring euer what we first decreed,
Since Reuels were proclaimd, Let now none bleede.

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.L: How well Diana can distinguish Times?
And sort her Censures? keeping to her selfe
The doome of Gods, leauing the rest to vs?
Come, cite them Criticus and then proceede.

SP.SPEAKER: Crit.
SP.L: First Philautia (for she was the first)
Then light Gelaia, in Aglaias name,
Thirdly Phantaste, and Moria next,
Mayne follies all, and of the Female crue;
Amorphus, or Eucosmos counterfet,
Voluptuous Hedon ta'ne for Eupathes,
Brazen Anaides, and Asotus last,
With his too Pages Morus, and Prosaites;
And thou the Trauailers Euill, Cos, approach,
Impostors all, and male Deformities.

SP.SPEAKER: Arete.
SP.L: Nay forward, for I delegate my power,
And will, that at thy mercy they do stand
Whom they so oft, so plainely scornd before:
" Tis vertue which they want, and wanting it,
" Honour no garment to their backes can fit.
Now Criticus, vse your Discretion.

SP.SPEAKER: Crit.
SP.L: Adored Cynthia, and bright Arete;
Another might seeme fitter for this tasque
Then Criticus, but that you iudge not so:
For I (not to appeare vindicatiue,
Or mindfull of Contempts, which I contemn'd
As done of Impotence) must be remisse;
Who as I was the Author in some sort,
To worke their knowledge into Cynthias sight,
So should be much seuerer to reuenge
The indignity, hence issuing to her Name:
But ther's not one of these, who are vnpaind,
Or by themselues vnpunished; for Vice
Is like a fury to the vitious minde,
And turnes Delight it selfe to Punishment.
But we must forward to define their Doome;
You are Offenders, that must be confest.
Do you confesse it?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: We doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Crit.
SP.L: And that you merit sharpe Correction?

SP.SPEAKER: Omnes.
SP.L: We doe.

SP.SPEAKER: Crit.
SP.L: Then we (reseruing vnto Delias grace,
Her farther pleasure, and to Arete
What Delia graunteth) thus do sentence you.
That from this place (for Penance knowne of all,
Since you haue drunke so deeply of Selfe-loue)
You (two and two) singing a Palinode,
March to your seuerall homes by Nioes stone,
And offer vp two teares a piece thereon;
That it may change the name, as you must change,
And of a stone be called Weeping Crosse:
Because it standeth crosse of Cynthias way,
One of whose names is sacred TRIVIA.
And after penance thus perform'd, you passe
In like set order; not as Midas did
To wash his Golde off into Tagus streame;
But to the Well of Knowledge, Helicon,
Where, purged of your present Maladies,
(Which are nor few, nor sender) you become
Such as you faine would seeme; and then returne
Offring your seruice to great Cynthia.
This is your Sentence, if the Goddesse please
To ratefie it with her high Consent:
" The scope of wise Mirth vnto fruit is bent.

SP.SPEAKER: Cyn.
SP.L: We do approoue thy Censure Criticu▪
Which Mercury, thy true propitious friend,
(A Dity, next Ioue, belou'd of vs,)
Will vndertake to see exactly done.
And for this seruice of Discouery
Perform'd by thee, in honor of our name,
We vow to guerdon it with such due grace,
As shall become our Bountie, and thy Place.
" Princes that would their People should do well,
" Must at themselues begin, as at the heads;
" For men by their example patterne out
" Their Imitations, and reguard of Lawes:
" A vertuous Court, a world to vertue drawes.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: From Spanish shrugs, French faces, Smirks, Irps, and all affected Humors.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercury defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: From secret friends, sweet Seruants, Loues, Doues, and such Phantastique Humors.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: ood Mercury defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Amor.
SP.P: From stabbing of Armes, Flap-dragons, Healths, Whiffes, and all such swaggering Humors.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercurie defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: From wauing of Fannes, coy Glaunces, Glicks, Cringes, and all such simpring Humors.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercury defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: From making loue by Attourney, courting of Pup∣pts, and paying for new acquaintance.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercury defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: From perfum'd Dogs, Monkeys, Sparrowes, Dildos, and Parachitos.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercury defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: From wearing Bracelets of Hayre, Shoo-tyes, Gloues, Garters, and Rings with Poesies.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercury defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: From Pargetting, Painting, Slieking, Glazing, and Renewing old riueld Faces.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercury defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: From Squiring to Tilt-yards, Play-Houses, Page∣ants, and all such Publique places.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercury defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Phan.
SP.P: From entertaining one Gallant to gull another, and making Fooles of eyther.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercury defend vs.

SP.SPEAKER: Amo.
SP.P: From Belying Ladyes fauors, Noble-mens counte∣nance, coyning counterfet Imployments, vain-glorious taking to them other mens Seruices, and all selfe-louing Humors.

SP.SPEAKER: Chorus.
SP.P: Good Mercury defend vs.

LG.HEAD: CANT.
LG.L: NOw each one dry his weeping Eyes,
and to the Well of Knowledge hast;
we may of sweeter waters taste:
The Grace of Cynthia, and her Court.

DIV1.HEAD: Epilogus▪
DIV1.L: GEntles, be't knowne to you, since I went in
I am turn'd Rimer; and do thus beginne:
The Author (iealous, how your sence doth take
His trauayles) hath enioyned me to make
Some short, and Ceremonious Epilogue;
But if I yet know what, I am a Rogue:
He ties me to such Lawes, as quite distract
My thoughts; and would a Yeare of time exact.
I neither must be Faint, Remisse, nor Sory,
Sower, Serious, Confident, nor Peremptory:
But betwixt these. Lets see? to lay the blame
Vpon the Childrens Action, that were lame.
To craue your Fauours with a begging knee,
Were to distrust the Writers faculty;
To promise better at the next we bring,
Prorogues disgrace, commends not any thing.
Stifly to stand on this, and proudly approoue
The Play, might taxe the Maker of Selfe-loue.
Ile onely speake, what I haue heard him say;
By God 'tis good, and if you lik't, you may,

Q.L: Ecce rubet quidam, pallet, stupet, oscitat, odit.
Hoc volo: nunc nobis carmina nostra placent.
